Scholars have debated whether Dickens was consciously using these stereotypes or if the portrayal was influenced by the cultural and historical context of his time. Some argue that Dickens was using the Micawber character to critique the failings of the British class system, rather than to promote antisemitism.

Despite these nuances, many critics and historians believe that Dickens' portrayal of Jewish characters, especially Mr. Micawber, reinforced harmful stereotypes that were prevalent at the time. This led to modern accusations of antisemitism in his work, even though Dickens himself was known for his progressive views and empathy towards the poor and marginalized.

In summary, Dickens was accused of following antisemitic stereotypes because his character Mr. Micawber was seen as reinforcing negative and stereotypical portrayals of Jewish people, which were common in 19th-century Britain.
